prior_works.title: Probabilities of Causation: Bounds and Identification
prior_works.role: Foundational formulation of causal attribution for binary outcomes (PN, PS, PNS) with identification/bounding under assumptions like monotonicity and exogeneity.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper generalizes this binary attribution paradigm by defining posterior causal estimands for continuous outcomes that conceptually parallel PN/PS-type quantities and relying on similar monotonicity-style assumptions for identification.

prior_works.title: Direct and Indirect Effects
prior_works.role: Introduced natural direct and indirect effects and the mediation formula in a counterfactual framework.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed posterior natural direct effect for continuous outcomes is grounded in Pearl’s NDE concept and adopts analogous cross-world causal reasoning.

prior_works.title: Identification, Inference and Sensitivity Analysis for Causal Mediation Effects
prior_works.role: Formalized sequential ignorability as a practical set of conditions for identifying natural direct/indirect effects and provided estimation strategies.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper invokes sequential ignorability to identify its posterior causal estimands, extending mediation-identification logic to a retrospective attribution setting with continuous outcomes.

prior_works.title: Identifiability and Exchangeability for Direct and Indirect Effects
prior_works.role: Early formalization of direct and indirect effects and conditions under which they are identified.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This foundational decomposition underlies the paper’s posterior total and natural direct effects, which adapt these ideas to attribution with multiple correlated causes and continuous outcomes.

prior_works.title: Monotone Treatment Response
prior_works.role: Introduced monotonicity assumptions to aid identification when full counterfactual information is unavailable.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s monotonicity assumption directly echoes Manski’s monotone response logic to help secure identifiability of posterior causal estimands.

prior_works.title: Correcting for Noncompliance in Randomized Trials Using Rank-Preserving Structural Failure Time Models
prior_works.role: Developed rank-preservation ideas that relate potential outcomes across interventions for continuous time-to-event outcomes.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The perfect positive rank condition in the paper parallels rank-preservation/comonotonicity notions, providing ordering structure needed to identify posterior effects for continuous outcomes.

prior_works.title: Bounds on Treatment Effects from Studies with Imperfect Compliance
prior_works.role: Established counterfactual bounding/identification techniques under monotonicity and partial compliance.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Their bounding-based identification perspective informs the paper’s strategy for establishing identifiability of posterior causal estimands under monotonicity-type assumptions.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—posterior causal estimands for retrospective attribution with continuous outcomes—builds directly on the binary-outcome attribution literature and mediation theory. Tian and Pearl’s work on probabilities of causation supplied the central attribution lens and the logic for identifying individual-level causal responsibility under assumptions like monotonicity, which this paper generalizes from binary to continuous outcomes via posterior intervention, total, and natural direct effects. Pearl’s formulation of natural direct/indirect effects provides the conceptual template for the posterior natural direct effect, while Robins and Greenland’s foundational treatment of direct/indirect effects anchors the causal decomposition the authors adapt to multi-cause settings.

Identification hinges on conditions that trace back to established frameworks. Imai, Keele, and Yamamoto’s sequential ignorability gives a practical, testable path to identifying natural effects; the present work adopts this to justify identification of posterior estimands given observed data. Manski’s monotone treatment response informs the monotonicity assumption the authors use to sharpen identification in observational settings. Finally, the paper’s perfect positive rank condition echoes rank-preserving ideas from Robins and Tsiatis, imposing an ordering on counterfactual outcomes that enables identification for continuous responses; the broader bounding perspective of Balke and Pearl motivates how monotonicity-type restrictions yield identifiable quantities when full information is unavailable. Together, these works directly scaffold the paper’s shift from binary to continuous-outcome causal attribution and its accompanying identification and estimation results.
